review: As part of the cable-cutting generation, I got this with the Sling TV deal as a way to ween myself from expensive (and unwatched) programming. I've played with Rokus in the past, as well as Apple TV, but I was mightily impressed with the feature set available from this device. It's snappy, doesn't lag while streaming, and provides me the most access to Sling, Netflix, and Prime. This was tested with an ethernet connection (as my wireless router is not very powerful). Regardless, my primary complaint is the lack of storage space on here (for example, I installed two games of about 2 gb each and I only have about 2.7 gb left). I might try to use a USB stick as supplemental storage, but we'll see. Another innovation that would be nice is an easier way to put the device to sleep when I'm away (it only uses about 6 watts at peak, but I'd rather it use as little as possible when not in use). As far as the cloud storage, it's nice, but not as fast in terms of utilization as a media pusher from multiple devices (ie: use my movie library and use this as a streaming device like I can on the Roku). Overall though, I really enjoy what Amazon is doing here. They've realized that as a company services are what sells, and they're providing plenty of that lately, which is why this device is so heavily integrated with their prime network. Kudos for that.

review: So far so good.  You don't get 5 stars because finding free content can be a bit daunting.  That isn't so much a problem with the device but with how Amazon presents the information.  Prime videos should be separated from the pay stuff.  That being said, set up was a simple as unpack the box, hook up the wires and go.  The hardest part was finding the wireless network password and entering it.  Once done, watch the little introduction video and away you go.  Streaming was as advertised, voice search really works, video quality is excellent.  I am certainly glad I bought this gadget and sorry I waited so long to do so.
